But we really need the full force of the legislature behind this.  Especially as long as the @GOP remains committed to subsidizing losers rather than embracing markets, and pretending that the laws of physics can be denied.  Executive orders aren't enough.

Worth noting that the Biden White House has been leaning into this issue as well: https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2021/05/20/executive-order-on-climate-related-financial-risk/

And it's why @brianschatz and I have been pushing for our regulators to model, anticipate and protect now, before its too late.  https://casten.house.gov/media/press-releases/casten-schatz-introduce-legislation-ensure-us-financial-system-prepared-climate
This "transition risk" is in addition to the physical risks created by property loss (fires, floods, etc) that climate change poses to our financial system.
But does run the risk of destabilizing corners of our financial markets, and we need to make sure our regulators are vigilant against broader fin market contagion.

That wonkiness aside, it's why I've been so focused on making sure these shifts don't destabilize our financial markets.   A lot of capital is shifting all at once in response to market forces, towards cleaner energy sources.  That's good for the environment and your wallet.
(Because capex cycles are so long and market fundamentals are, well, fundamental.  But dumb money and/or bad contracts make the timing of liquidity moves hard to predict)
To be clear, this has been coming for a long time.  I've long maintained that it's easy to predict what's going to happen in energy markets - it's just hard to predict the timing.

This is really interesting.  Even in the absence of sufficiently strong GHG policy, markets increasingly prefer the risk profile of clean cheap energy that doesn't have the price volatility of fossil fuel. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-11-09/cost-of-capital-widens-for-fossil-fuel-producers-green-insight?sref=JMv1OWqN

Because to me, true patriotism will always be how we honor the sacrifices those in uniform have made for the rest of us. Not just on Veterans Day, but every other day of the year, too.

So while I can’t fly combat missions anymore or help drag Soldiers from a burning Blackhawk if the worst should strike again, I can use my current role—serving no longer from the cockpit but the Senate—to ensure our Armed Forces are the strongest they can be.

My buddies thought I was dead—I was quite literally in pieces.

They risked their own lives to bring my body back to my family.

From the moment I woke up in Walter Reed 11 days later, I vowed to find a way to repay them as well as all those who sacrifice so much for our nation.

When that RPG tore through the cockpit of the helicopter I was co-piloting, it took my legs, partial use of my right arm and nearly my life. I wouldn’t have lasted the hour if it weren’t for my buddies who refused to leave me behind.

Business as usual and the status quo are death sentences. We must make climate central to all policymaking domestically, promote justice for those bearing the brunt of this crisis, ensure polluters pay, and lead by example with ambition, intersectionality, and conviction.

The draft agreement for the first time takes steps to phase out fossil fuels. President Biden made historic climate financing pledges. And the U.S. and China made a joint commitment to cooperate to combat climate change. Yet, it is not enough simply to take these important steps.

#COP26 is ending, but our climate work continues in greater urgency. The United States and other countries who have contributed the most to the climate crisis must be leading efforts to do the most to reverse its course.

The Bipartisan Infrastructure and Investment Jobs Act represents a monumental investment in the future of California and our nation. This package reauthorizes and fully funds our programs through FY23 and includes $550B in new project funding.

If the U.S. wants to lead the world on climate justice, we can start by passing the Build Back Better Act without delay - and by making oil and gas companies pay for what they've done. My proposal would raise $500 billion from the worst polluters to help meet our climate goals.

From #COP26 to the halls of Congress, we urgently need to stand up to the fossil fuel industry. These companies have lied to the public and bought off governments for decades - and as we cope with worsening storms, heat waves, and drought, they continue to profit.
